title: EPCIS Event based Traceability in Pharmceutical Supply Chains via Automated Generation of Linked Pedigrees

author: Monika Solanki, Aston Business School, Aston University

segmentation: So today I'll be talking about some work that is been going on at the University of Aston where I work on supply chains.
So essentially.
The motivation behind this work is exactly this.
What you see the idea is that we have supply chains and in supply chains products move between stakeholders and you want to do tracking and tracing.
You want to know where your products are at at certain points in time so.
The key idea behind this is a notion of visibility.
So visibility as is defined by GS1, which is one of the standard organizations I'll be talking about later.
So visibility as defined by GS One is the ability to know exactly where things are at any point in time and where they have been and why.
So we need to know where things have been an, what was the business process, which led them to being there, and why they were there.
So essentially, the idea behind enabling visibility is that of data and information sharing.
So what we want to do is we want to enable knowledge and data within the supply chain to be interlinked and shared in such a way that they are available for to all the stakeholders.

And this is not just important from a regulatory perspective but it's also important now nowadays because consumers are becoming more and more aware of where the product has come from an all the ethical and moral reasons behind.
Consuming a specific product.
So, uh, essentially the case study that will be using throughout this talk today is that of the pharmaceutical supply chain.
So this is how a typical pharmaceutical supply chain would look like.
So you have the manufacturer of pharmaceutical products and then you have the warehouse or the wholesaler where the products are being stopped.

From there they go to the distribution center and then finally to the pharmacies from where the consumers ultimately buy them and what we see is that at each and every stage of the product moving from one supplier from one stakeholder to the other.
There are several processes that take place, so the product is first of all manufacturer.
Then it's aggregated in boxes, then it is shipped out and when it is received at the other stakeholders and it is again D aggregated and then shipped into different containers.
So on and so forth.
So a specific product at any point in the supply chain goes through several different processes and this is 1 product which is traveling between several stakeholders.
So we need to track what happens to this product at each and every.
Of these different stages.
So essentially what is important specifically within pharmaceutical supply chain is this issue of counterfeiting.

Now counterfeiting has been known to account for 5 to 8% of the pharmaceutical pharmaceutical drugs which are being sent out within the supply chain and that is why it is really important to address this problem of counterfeit detection at the data level as well as the physical level which which is being done.
So how do we want to do this?
So of course this is not random and ad hoc, so we have this legal requirement from the drug supply Chain Security Act.
So in November 2013, President Obama actually signed.
Data quality and Security Act and the main emphasis on the of this act was this drug supply chain.
Quality control kind of a thing where.
Required to provide interoperable systems that will enable the tracking and tracing of drugs within the supply chain and now this is a legal requirement.

So from January 2015 in the US, All manufacturers or providers or pharmaceutical drugs will have to make sure that this system is in place that allows them to track and trig trace drugs when they are moving within the supply chain.
So essentially, how do we want to do this?
So for this we want to use the GS one standards now GS one.

Is this nonprofit organization which is responsible for providing specifications to enable trace ability within supply chains and they have these two core specifications, which is the PCI S and the CBV specification.
So these will be the foundations of the work that I'll be presenting and within the GS One Standards Organization there is this one specific body called the Secure Supply Chain Task Force.

Which is responsible for then giving out informal guidelines which manufacturers an whole handling agents of supply chain drugs within the pharmaceutical sector can can use to actually provide these trace ability specifications.
So the code notion of weird is that of a PC, which is the electronic product code.
So we will use a PC as our foundation for tracking and tracing pharmaceutical drugs.

The specification is ICIS, which is the electronic product code Information Services and this comes along with a companion specification called the Core business vocabulary that gives you the terminology that you need to implement a Bcis.
And finally these two standards of ICIS and CB use events as the basic abstract notion.
For doing trace ability.

First of all, we want to use the API specification and the notion of the the tracking interesting mechanism given given by the specification to do Provenant base Providence based tracking and tracing within the supply chain.

What we have in this specification is the notion of events, and there are basically one generic and for typical events what we are interested over over here is these three events, which is the object event.
Which is, you know, when a EPC is assigned to a product.
The aggregation event when the events are when the objects are being packed, and then the transaction event which actually says that corresponding to a specific business order.
A particular shipment was made.
So these three events basically capture.
What happens to the product when it moves, when it is, when it is being handled at a particular stakeholders premises.
These actually these three events happen at each and every of these stakeholders who are responsible for handling the products in the supply chain.

Electronic product code.

The kind of mechanism that you would need to describe the PCI specification and into logical form.

That has also been modeled as CB vocab.
That is another ontology.

Extracted so the they're basically extracted in terms of time intervals, so we have tumbling windows and then once you've extracted those and then what we do is based on the business trip.

And once we have done that, then we can start our counterfeit EPC detection.

So what we do is we look at each and every event we check if the if the business type essentially EPC counterfeit EPC direction is checking is checking that something that was commissioned or given an EPC appears in the aggregation an anything in the aggregation which has an EPC which was not seen in the object event is supposed to be counterfeit.
So based on that we check the packing event and see if the event which was seen here the EPC which was senior.
Was actually a part of the commissioning event, so this is our counterfeit detection mechanism.
We use sparkle queries to do all these checks and we have an implementation that is running on top of stream processor to direct the count of it and this is an easy approach.

So to summarize, what we've done in in this process of doing, tracking and tracing within the pharmaceutical supply chain is actually try and understand that if the paper pedigree trail was to be replaced by a linked data powered pedigree trail, then what would be the implications?
So what would what would be the kind of pedigree generation time that we were looking at based on these realistic volumes of EPS events and what would be the counterfeit EPC detection time which is?
A very important part of within these within the specifically within the pharmaceutical supply chain.

Having said that, this particular approach is really domain agnostic, so if one were to put pick this approach up for the even let's say for the Agri food supply chain it would pretty much work the same, except that what you would need to change are the times the number of pieces per event and the aggregation and the decommissioning steps in the process.
